epidemiology: Leading cause of death globally. Common in adults over 50, especially males and individuals with risk factors such as diabetes, hypertension, smoking, and dyslipidemia.
treatment_protocol: ECG + Troponin → Angiography → PCI or CABG based on lesion severity

epidemiology: Incidence ~3 per 100,000/year. More common in men >60 years. Associated with hypertension, Marfan syndrome, and aortic aneurysm.
treatment_protocol: CT/TEE → Stabilize BP → Surgery (Type A) or stenting (Type B)

epidemiology: Prevalence increases with age. Primary causes: mitral valve prolapse, rheumatic disease, endocarditis. Common in elderly and patients with LV dysfunction.

emergency_markers: Acute MR due to papillary muscle rupture

treatment_protocol: Echo → Medical therapy → Surgery if severe MR or symptomatic

epidemiology: Annual incidence ~100 per 100,000. Risk increases with immobilization, surgery, malignancy, and hypercoagulable states. Massive PE can lead to hemodynamic collapse.
treatment_protocol: CTPA → Anticoagulation → Surgical embolectomy for unstable cases

epidemiology: Incidence ~10–20 per 100,000. More common in tall, thin males and those with underlying lung disease or trauma. Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening emergency.
treatment_protocol: Clinical diagnosis → Needle decompression → Chest tube → Surgery if indicated

epidemiology: Occurs in trauma, cancer, uremia, and post-cardiac surgery. Life-threatening if not rapidly treated. Incidence increasing with more cardiac procedures.
treatment_protocol: Echo → Pericardiocentesis → Surgery if recurrent

epidemiology: Prevalence ~10 per 100,000. Increases with age. More common in males and hypertensive patients. Often asymptomatic until large or ruptured.
treatment_protocol: CT/MRI → Monitor if <5.5 cm → Surgery if >5.5 cm or symptomatic

epidemiology: Complication of pneumonia, trauma, or surgery. Seen more in immunocompromised and elderly. Common cause of prolonged febrile illness in children.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Drainage → Decortication if not resolving

epidemiology: Congenital form occurs in 1 in 3000–5000 live births. Acquired form seen in malignancy or prolonged intubation. Presents early in neonates or with chronic aspiration in adults.
treatment_protocol: Diagnosis via imaging → Surgical repair (thoracotomy or thoracoscopy)

epidemiology: Often a complication of aspiration pneumonia. More common in alcoholics, elderly, or those with poor oral hygiene. Right lower lobe most commonly affected.
treatment_protocol: Antibiotics → Drainage → Surgery for complications

epidemiology: Rare congenital lung malformation where a portion of lung tissue is nonfunctional and receives blood from systemic circulation. More common in males and typically diagnosed in childhood.
treatment_protocol: CT angiogram → Confirm diagnosis → Surgery

epidemiology: Congenital in most cases, representing ~10% of congenital heart defects. May present in infancy or later in life depending on severity.
treatment_protocol: Echo → Balloon dilation or surgery based on severity

epidemiology: Serious complication following lung surgery, trauma, or infection (e.g., TB). Incidence varies, ~2% after pneumonectomy. More common in malnourished or immunocompromised patients.
treatment_protocol: Imaging + bronchoscopy → Drain → Surgical repair

epidemiology: Rare germ cell tumor arising in the anterior mediastinum. Most common in young adults. Often asymptomatic unless large.
treatment_protocol: CT + tumor markers → Surgery if symptomatic or growing

epidemiology: Most common congenital chest wall deformity (90% of cases). Seen in 1 in 400–1000 live births. More common in males.
treatment_protocol: CT + PFTs → Consider surgery based on severity (Haller index)

epidemiology: Congenital narrowing of the aorta, found in ~5–8% of congenital heart defects. More common in males and often associated with Turner syndrome.

definitive: Balloon angioplasty with or without stenting

treatment_protocol: Echo → Imaging → Surgical or catheter-based repair

epidemiology: Rare benign congenital lesion. Found incidentally in ~1 per 100,000 individuals on imaging. Most are asymptomatic.

emergency_markers: Large size causing tamponade or airway compromise

treatment_protocol: Imaging → Observation or excision depending on size/symptoms

epidemiology: Common in IV drug users and patients with indwelling lines. Accounts for ~10% of all endocarditis cases.
treatment_protocol: Blood cultures + Echo → IV antibiotics → Surgery if not responsive

epidemiology: Rare vascular abnormality often associated with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT). Can cause paradoxical emboli or hypoxemia.
treatment_protocol: CT + Angiography → Embolization or surgery

epidemiology: Compression of subclavian vessels at the thoracic outlet. Affects 3–80 per 100,000 annually. Most common in young adults and athletes.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Conservative → Surgery if severe or thrombotic

epidemiology: Rare congenital heart anomaly where the left or right atrium is divided by a fibromuscular membrane. Represents <0.1% of congenital heart diseases.
treatment_protocol: Echo → Confirm obstruction → Surgical resection

epidemiology: Seen in neonates, trauma, vasculitis (e.g., Goodpasture), and cardiac failure. Can be life-threatening due to rapid blood loss and airway compromise.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Bronchoscopy/Imaging → Embolization or surgery

epidemiology: Can occur post-surgical repair of congenital heart defects (e.g., Tetralogy of Fallot), pulmonary hypertension, or carcinoid syndrome. Usually asymptomatic until severe.
treatment_protocol: Echo/MRI → Monitor or surgery if symptomatic or severe regurgitation

epidemiology: Rare complication after right pneumonectomy due to excessive mediastinal shift, compressing airways or esophagus. More common in children.

definitive: Insertion of tissue expanders or prostheses to reposition mediastinum

treatment_protocol: CT/Bronchoscopy → Prosthesis insertion or airway stenting

epidemiology: Congenital cystic lung lesion seen in ~1 in 25,000 live births. Diagnosed prenatally or in infancy. May be asymptomatic or cause respiratory distress.
treatment_protocol: CT/MRI → Surgical resection in symptomatic or enlarging lesions

epidemiology: Accumulation of pus in the pleural space, often following pneumonia, thoracic surgery, or trauma. Common in children and immunocompromised adults.
treatment_protocol: Image-guided drainage → Antibiotics → Surgery if unresolved

epidemiology: Localized necrosis of lung parenchyma due to microbial infection. Common in aspiration, alcoholism, and immunosuppressed patients.
treatment_protocol: CT + Culture → Antibiotics → Drain/resect if unresponsive

epidemiology: Accumulation of chyle in the pleural space due to thoracic duct injury. Can occur post cardiothoracic surgery, trauma, or malignancy.
treatment_protocol: Pleural tap + imaging → Conservative → Surgery if persistent

epidemiology: Very rare malignant lung tumor resembling fetal lung tissue. Most cases diagnosed in adults under 40 years. Aggressive behavior.
treatment_protocol: CT + Biopsy → Resection + adjunct therapy

epidemiology: Accumulation of fluid in pericardial sac causing cardiac compression. Causes include malignancy, TB, uremia, and trauma.
treatment_protocol: Echo → Emergency pericardiocentesis → Window if recurrent

epidemiology: Congenital anomaly where a portion of lung tissue receives systemic arterial blood supply and lacks normal bronchial connection. More common in lower lobes.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Resection if symptomatic or risk of complications

disease: Pulmonary Hypertension (Secondary to Congenital Heart Disease)
epidemiology: Common in untreated left-to-right shunts like VSD, ASD, or PDA. Progresses to Eisenmenger syndrome if uncorrected.
treatment_protocol: Echo + Cath → Treat defect + supportive care

epidemiology: Abnormal communication between bronchial tree and pleural space. Occurs post lung surgery, trauma, or infection. Associated with high morbidity.
treatment_protocol: Drain + Treat infection → Surgical repair

epidemiology: Rare congenital vascular anomaly where left pulmonary artery arises from the right and compresses the airway. Presents in infancy with stridor.
treatment_protocol: CT + Bronchoscopy → Surgery

epidemiology: Extremely rare malignancy of the pericardium, associated with asbestos exposure. Often presents late with pericardial effusion.
treatment_protocol: Echo/Imaging → Biopsy → Surgery + chemo/radiation

epidemiology: Congenital or acquired abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus. Most common type in neonates is proximal esophageal atresia with distal TEF.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize neonate → Contrast study → Surgery

epidemiology: Herniation of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity due to diaphragm defect, most commonly Bochdalek type. Occurs in ~1 in 2,500 live births.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Imaging → Surgery when stable

epidemiology: Rare interstitial lung disease seen in young adults, especially smokers. Involves proliferation of Langerhans cells forming granulomas and cysts.
treatment_protocol: CT → Biopsy → Manage or transplant

epidemiology: Benign congenital anomaly found incidentally on imaging. May enlarge and compress adjacent structures. Located usually at right cardiophrenic angle.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Monitor or excise

epidemiology: Abnormal connection between pulmonary artery and vein, bypassing capillaries. Often associated with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT).
treatment_protocol: CT/echo → Embolize or resect

epidemiology: Rare congenital or acquired abnormal communication between a coronary artery and a cardiac chamber or vessel. Can lead to volume overload or ischemia.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Assess flow → Closure if significant

epidemiology: Congenital narrowing of the aorta, typically near the ductus arteriosus. Commonly detected in childhood or adolescence.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Repair or stent if gradient significant

epidemiology: Congenital narrowing of the pulmonary valve. May occur in isolation or as part of congenital syndromes. Common cause of right ventricular outflow obstruction.
treatment_protocol: Echo → Balloon or surgery if moderate-severe

epidemiology: Protrusion of the sternum and ribs due to overgrowth of cartilage. More common in adolescent males. Often cosmetic but may impair lung function.
treatment_protocol: Assess severity → Bracing → Surgery if needed

epidemiology: Flaccidity of the tracheal support cartilage, leading to collapse especially during expiration. May be congenital or acquired.
treatment_protocol: Bronchoscopy → Supportive → Surgery if needed
